Getting the Code

Bring on the code!

You can recursively clone and initialize all of Polymer’s submodules with a single git command.

To get the code, run:

git clone git://github.com/Polymer/polymer-all.git --recursive

This creates a polymer-all/ folder with the following top-level files and folders:

  • platform/ — The platform shims and polyfills.
  • polymer/polymer.js — The Polymer kernel
  • polymer-elements/ — A collection of core utility elements.
  • polymer-ui-elements/ — A collection of UI elements.
  • projects/ — Larger examples, demos, and tools that use Polymer.
  • Each platform (polyfill) also has a sibling repo.

More on repository structure is below.

Test your environment

To check that your development environment is ready, start a local web server and run one of the included sample projects:

  1. Start a local web server in the folder where you have polymer-all/ checked out.
  2. In your browser, navigate to http://localhost/toolkit-ui/workbench/menu.html, or whichever port you started the server on. You should see a menu of items, as shown below.

About branches

See Branching Workflow.

Updating Polymer submodules

Periodically, we will update the project’s submodules on GitHub. To update your local copy’s submodules, run the following command from the polymer-all/ folder:

git submodule update --init --recursive

Repository structure

The entirety of the Polymer is composed of a number of Git repositories. All are included as submodules in the main polymer-all repository. However, understanding the various pieces will help you navigate the codebase.

We have factored our repositories into atomic chunks. For example, the following repositories may be useful individually:

  • CustomElements
  • HTMLImports
  • ShadowDOM
  • mdv
  • PointerGestures

Some repositories depend on others in Polymer and must be siblings of the same parent directory to function completely:

  • polymer
  • platform
  • toolkit-ui

/platform repository

github.com/polymer/platform

Each new web platform feature has a corresponding polyfill repository. The reasoning for this is two-fold:

  1. make the polyfills work across all modern browsers
  2. each polyfill can stand on its own and be used à la carte in projects.

The platform repository references each of the polyfills as a sibling directory, and contains integration tests, loader, and build tools for the amalgamated polyfills.

See Tooling Strategy for information.

/polymer repository

github.com/polymer/polymer

The polymer repository contains the guts of the project. It expects the platform polyfill repo to be a sibling directory, and hosts the Polymer kernel with its tools and tests.

If you want to see the development activity, checkout the master branch directly:

git clone -b master https://github.com/Polymer/polymer.git --recursive

Remember: If you don't specify master, you'll get the stable branch by default. See Branching Workflow for more info.

/toolkit-ui repository

github.com/polymer/toolkit-ui

The toolkit-ui repository contains examples of the types of things you can do when writing a Polymer element.

  • elements/ — g-* custom element definitions.
  • workbench/ — demos of the Polymer-style elements found in elements/.
